news_summary: NASA's advancements in Artemis missions, heat shield technology, and ongoing Mars exploration demonstrate significant progress and innovation in deep space exploration.
news_summary_fr: Les avancées de la NASA dans le cadre des missions Artemis, de la technologie des boucliers thermiques et de l'exploration continue de Mars témoignent des progrès et des innovations significatifs réalisés dans le domaine de l'exploration spatiale lointain.
news_summary_es: Los avances de la NASA en las misiones Artemis, la tecnología de escudos térmicos y la exploración continua de Marte demuestran un progreso y una innovación significativos en la exploración del espacio profundo.

articles.title: NASA Armstrong Contributions Propel Artemis, Deep Space Innovation
articles.summary: NASA is leveraging expertise, capabilities, and partnerships across its centers to make Artemis campaign and deep space exploration safer, more reliable, and efficient. At NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, contributions include technical leadership, unique flight-testing capabilities, and management of a key technology program that advances critical exploration concepts. Artemis II is an […]
articles.content:
NASA is leveraging expertise, capabilities, and partnerships across its centers to make Artemis campaign and deep space exploration safer, more reliable, and efficient. At NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, contributions include technical leadership, unique flight-testing capabilities, and management of a key technology program that advances critical exploration concepts.

Artemis II is an upcoming challenging test flight, and the lessons learned will directly prepare NASA to return humans to the surface of the Moon on Artemis III and beyond, as well as send the first astronauts – Americans – to Mars.

Gulfstream G-III aircraft collects heat shield data

A NASA Gulfstream G-III aircraft lifts off from NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, on Tuesday, Jan. 20, 2026. Modifications were made to the aircraft to enable it to join three others flying at different altitudes to capture a complete view of the Orion spacecraft’s heat shield during Artemis II reentry. This effort is part of NASA’s Scientifically Calibrated In-Flight Imagery project. NASA/Carla Thomas

As preparations continue for the Artemis II launch, NASA Armstrong technicians modified a Gulfstream G-III to collect heat shield data during Orion’s reentry. As part of NASA’s Scientifically Calibrated In-Flight Imagery, the G-III will join other aircraft to capture Orion’s thermal protection data.

“Before the Artemis II mission begins, the aircraft will complete a dress rehearsal over the Pacific Ocean to verify the airborne system performance,” said Robert Navarro, NASA Armstrong support aircraft fleet project manager.

Technicians at NASA’s Johnson Space Center in Houston installed sensors and special windows for the imagery mission with assistance from NASA Armstrong technicians.

Measuring Orion’s reentry heat

Inside the Neil Armstrong Operations and Checkout Building high bay at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida, from left, technicians Kenny Leidner, Diamond ScharSenstine, Russ Novak and Darlene Beville with ASRC Federal, inspect AVOCAT block bonding on the Artemis II heat shield on July 2, 2020. The heat shield is one of the most critical elements of Orion and will protect the capsule and astronauts during reentry through Earth’s atmosphere. Artemis II is the first crewed mission in a series of missions to the Moon and on to Mars. Artemis II will confirm all of the Orion spacecraft’s systems operate as designed in the actual environment of deep space with astronauts aboard. NASA/Isaac Watson

NASA Armstrong also assists with the Orion heat shield spectrometer system for Artemis II. The system is designed to collect shock layer radiation data from the heat shield during atmospheric entry, data that will be used to enhance astronaut safety.

NASA Armstrong’s expertise in integrating technologies, high reliability flight test instrumentation, and flight operations are a match for some Artemis and deep space projects.

“There is nothing that can go to space or come back without going through the atmosphere, so our mission of atmospheric flight research and test is very relevant,” said Brad Flick, NASA Armstrong center director. “We specialize in testing technologies and working through the challenges of flight.”

Testing Orion’s launch abort system

Under the watchful eyes of technicians, a crane positions the Orion Pad Abort-1 Abort Flight Test module for mass properties testing in the Flight Loads Laboratory at NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California. NASA/Tony Landis

Teamwork was on full display at NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, on Aug. 13, 2009, as engineers and technicians prepared the Pad Abort-1 vehicle – the Orion launch abort system development test article. After assembly and integration, the mock crew capsule was transported to the U.S. Army’s White Sands Missile Range in New Mexico where it successfully completed its test on May 6, 2010. NASA/Tony Landis

NASA Armstrong demonstrated that approach when it tested a system to enable Artemis astronauts to escape harm in the event of an emergency on the ground, or in the boost phase of the Orion spacecraft.

“We proved the system could get the astronauts to safety,” said Cathy Bahm, project manager for NASA’s Low Boom Flight Demonstrator. Earlier in her career, she played key roles in engineering, integration, and management for Pad Abort-1 and Ascent Abort-2 that validated the Orion spacecraft’s launch abort system.

Armstrong integrated and tested the capsule and abort system and operations at the launch abort pad at White Sands Test Facility in New Mexico for the Pad Abort-1 test.

“Hopefully we’ll never need it, but knowing I contributed to the safety of future astronauts is a highlight of my career,” Bahm said. “Looking back on it, it was a tremendous accomplishment for the center, the team, and a contribution to the future of space travel.”

Flight Opportunities program advances space tech

A NASA F/A-18 research aircraft flies near NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in Edwards, California, on Feb. 24, 2025, testing a commercial precision landing technology for future space missions. The Psionic Space Navigation Doppler Lidar (PSNDL) system is installed in a pod located under the right wing of the aircraft. NASA

Another contributor to future space travel is the Flight Opportunities program, which matures capabilities needed for NASA missions and commercial applications while strategically investing in the growth of the U.S. commercial spaceflight industry. NASA Armstrong manages the program, which supports flight testing of promising technologies, instruments, and experiments aboard commercial vehicles. Part of the agency’s Space Technology Mission Directorate, the program identifies the best ideas – from industry, academia, and NASA researchers – for flight testing.

Flight Opportunities advanced precision landing and optical communications technologies for future lunar missions.

“Landing safely in shadowed lunar regions is critical,” said Greg Peters, Flight Opportunities program manager.

Another deep space technology Flight Opportunities supported was a vibration isolation platform that helped provide extremely precise pointing for the Deep Space Optical Communications technology demonstration. That instrument used lasers to transmit data between Earth and the Psyche spacecraft from more than 215 million miles away, which could benefit future missions to Mars.

NASA Armstrong tested Doppler Lidar system navigation on an F/A-18 to prepare for Moon and Mars missions.

Contributions to Artemis, deep space exploration

April Torres and Angelo De La Rosa remove wire harnesses for signal input for the Orion Ascent Abort-2 vehicle from electrostatic discharge protective covers at NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in California. NASA/Lauren Hughes

NASA Armstrong’s work supporting Artemis and future deep space exploration missions also includes:

A NASA F/A-18 based at NASA Armstrong tested an autopilot for the SLS (Space Launch System) that proved sensors would work at the trajectory needed for landing on Mars.

NASA Armstrong researchers advanced a Fiber Optic Sensing System that flew in space for the first time on the Low Earth Orbit Flight Test of an Inflatable Decelerator mission.

NASA Armstrong researchers developed a cryogenic FOSS, called CryoFOSS, to support future deep space missions. CryoFOSS was used during testing of a system designed to liquefy oxygen – as it would on the Moon or Mars – for use as return-trip fuel. By producing fuel on-site, missions could avoid carrying return fuel from Earth, significantly reducing launch weight and overall mission cost.

NASA Armstrong staff were in the control rooms when the Orion spacecraft launch abort system was demonstrated.

Before the Ascent Abort-2 tests could advance, NASA Armstrong assisted with component testing and integration work.

NASA Armstrong photographers and videographers documented the Orion parachute tests in Yuma, Arizona.

Under the Artemis campaign, NASA is returning humans to the Moon for economic benefits, scientific discovery, and to prepare for crewed missions to Mars.
articles.reasoning: The article details NASA Armstrong Flight Research Center's significant contributions to the Artemis program and deep space exploration, including technical leadership, flight testing, and technology development that enhance astronaut safety and mission reliability. These efforts support the broader goal of returning humans to the Moon and eventually sending astronauts to Mars, representing a major positive impact on space exploration with broad scientific and societal benefits.
articles.personality_title: NASA Armstrong center powers Artemis missions with advanced flight testing and technology
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA’s Artemis program aims to return humans to the Moon and eventually send astronauts to Mars. Achieving this requires new technology and careful testing to keep astronauts safe and missions reliable.

**What happened** – NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center in California is playing a key role by leading technical work, testing spacecraft flight systems, and managing important technology programs. For example, Armstrong modified a Gulfstream G-III aircraft to collect heat shield data during the Artemis II spacecraft’s reentry. They also helped test the Orion spacecraft’s launch abort system, which can safely pull astronauts away from danger during launch emergencies.

**Impact** – Armstrong’s unique skills in flight testing and technology integration help make space missions safer and more efficient. Their work on heat shields, abort systems, and precision landing technologies directly improves astronaut safety and mission success. This support is essential as Artemis missions prepare to send humans deeper into space than ever before.

**What's next step** – The Armstrong team will continue flight tests and technology development for upcoming Artemis missions, including Artemis II’s crewed flight and Artemis III’s Moon landing. They will also support new tools like cryogenic fuel systems that could help astronauts produce rocket fuel on the Moon or Mars, reducing costs and challenges of space travel.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s Armstrong Flight Research Center is crucial in testing and developing technologies that make Artemis missions to the Moon and Mars safer and more reliable.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le centre Armstrong de la NASA propulse les missions Artemis grâce aux tests de vol avancés et à la technologie
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le programme Artemis de la NASA vise à renvoyer des humains sur la Lune et, à terme, envoyer des astronautes sur Mars. Cela nécessite de nouvelles technologies et des tests rigoureux pour assurer la sécurité des astronautes et la fiabilité des missions.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le centre de recherche en vol Armstrong de la NASA en Californie joue un rôle clé en dirigeant des travaux techniques, en testant les systèmes de vol des engins spatiaux et en gérant des programmes technologiques importants. Par exemple, Armstrong a modifié un avion Gulfstream G-III pour collecter des données sur le bouclier thermique lors de la rentrée atmosphérique du vaisseau Artemis II. Ils ont également aidé à tester le système d’éjection de la capsule Orion, capable de sauver les astronautes en cas d’urgence au lancement.

**Impact** – L’expertise unique d’Armstrong dans les tests de vol et l’intégration technologique rend les missions spatiales plus sûres et plus efficaces. Leur travail sur les boucliers thermiques, les systèmes d’éjection et les technologies d’atterrissage précis améliore directement la sécurité des astronautes et le succès des missions. Ce soutien est essentiel pour préparer les missions Artemis à envoyer des humains plus loin dans l’espace que jamais.

**Prochaine étape** – L’équipe Armstrong poursuivra les tests en vol et le développement technologique pour les prochaines missions Artemis, y compris le vol habité d’Artemis II et l’atterrissage sur la Lune d’Artemis III. Ils soutiendront aussi de nouveaux outils comme les systèmes de carburant cryogénique pour aider les astronautes à produire du carburant sur la Lune ou Mars, réduisant ainsi les coûts et les difficultés des voyages spatiaux.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le centre de recherche en vol Armstrong de la NASA est essentiel pour tester et développer des technologies qui rendent les missions Artemis vers la Lune et Mars plus sûres et plus fiables.
articles.personality_title_es: El centro Armstrong de la NASA impulsa las misiones Artemis con pruebas de vuelo avanzadas y tecnología
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El programa Artemis de la NASA busca regresar humanos a la Luna y, eventualmente, enviar astronautas a Marte. Para lograr esto, se necesitan nuevas tecnologías y pruebas cuidadosas que mantengan a los astronautas seguros y las misiones confiables.

**Qué pasó** – El Centro de Investigación de Vuelo Armstrong de la NASA en California desempeña un papel clave al liderar trabajos técnicos, probar sistemas de vuelo de naves espaciales y gestionar programas tecnológicos importantes. Por ejemplo, Armstrong modificó un avión Gulfstream G-III para recoger datos del escudo térmico durante la reentrada de la nave Artemis II. También ayudaron a probar el sistema de aborto de lanzamiento de la nave Orion, que puede alejar a los astronautas del peligro en emergencias durante el lanzamiento.

**Impacto** – Las habilidades únicas de Armstrong en pruebas de vuelo e integración tecnológica ayudan a hacer las misiones espaciales más seguras y eficientes. Su trabajo en escudos térmicos, sistemas de aborto y tecnologías de aterrizaje preciso mejora directamente la seguridad de los astronautas y el éxito de las misiones. Este apoyo es esencial mientras las misiones Artemis preparan a los humanos para viajar más lejos en el espacio que nunca.

**Próximo paso** – El equipo de Armstrong continuará con las pruebas de vuelo y el desarrollo tecnológico para las próximas misiones Artemis, incluyendo el vuelo tripulado de Artemis II y el alunizaje de Artemis III. También apoyarán nuevas herramientas como sistemas de combustible criogénico que podrían ayudar a los astronautas a producir combustible en la Luna o Marte, reduciendo costos y retos del viaje espacial.

**Conclusión en una frase** – El Centro de Investigación de Vuelo Armstrong de la NASA es fundamental para probar y desarrollar tecnologías que hacen que las misiones Artemis a la Luna y Marte sean más seguras y confiables.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a sleek, stylized NASA Gulfstream G-III aircraft soaring above a calm Pacific Ocean beneath a softly glowing sky, with a translucent, abstract representation of the Orion spacecraft’s heat shield glowing faintly in the background, and subtle geometric patterns symbolizing advanced flight testing and safety technologies surrounding the scene.

articles.title: NASA Heat Shield Tech Contributes to America’s Space Industry
articles.summary: This Jan. 29, 2026, photo captures the streak the Varda Space Industries W-5 capsule made while returning to Earth. The capsule uses a protective heat shield Varda produced made of cutting-edge material it licensed from NASA. The material, known as C-PICA (Conformal Phenolic Impregnated Carbon Ablator), provides a stronger, less expensive, and more efficient thermal protection […]
articles.content:
Varda Space Industries/William Godward

This Jan. 29, 2026, photo captures the streak the Varda Space Industries W-5 capsule made while returning to Earth. The capsule uses a protective heat shield Varda produced made of cutting-edge material it licensed from NASA. The material, known as C-PICA (Conformal Phenolic Impregnated Carbon Ablator), provides a stronger, less expensive, and more efficient thermal protection coating to capsules, allowing them – and their valuable contents – to return to Earth safely.

Developed at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California’s Silicon Valley, C-PICA sets the standard for heat shields, reflecting the decades of expertise that NASA brings to designing, developing, and testing innovative thermal protection materials. This flight test of Varda-produced C-PICA was supported by NASA’s Flight Opportunities program.

Image credit: Varda Space Industries/William Godward
articles.reasoning: The article describes a successful application of NASA-developed heat shield technology (C-PICA) licensed to a private company, improving space capsule safety and efficiency. This represents a meaningful technological advancement with broad implications for the space industry and safe return of valuable payloads, benefiting society's space exploration capabilities.
articles.personality_title: NASA’s heat shield tech helps private space capsule return safely
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – NASA created a special heat shield material called C-PICA to protect spacecraft from the intense heat they face when returning to Earth. This material was developed at NASA’s Ames Research Center in California.

**What happened** – On January 29, 2026, the W-5 capsule from Varda Space Industries returned to Earth using a heat shield made from the C-PICA material. Varda licensed this technology from NASA and made the protective shield for their capsule, which helped it survive the fiery descent.

**Impact** – This event shows how NASA’s technology can be used by private companies to improve space travel. The C-PICA heat shield is stronger, cheaper, and works better than older materials. This means space capsules can carry valuable items back to Earth more safely and affordably.

**What’s next step** – NASA and private companies like Varda will likely continue working together to use and improve heat shield technology. This could lead to safer and more frequent space missions with better protection for equipment and experiments.

**One-sentence takeaway** – NASA’s advanced heat shield material helped a private company safely bring a space capsule back to Earth, showing important progress in space travel technology.
articles.personality_title_fr: La technologie de bouclier thermique de la NASA aide une capsule spatiale privée à revenir en toute sécurité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La NASA a créé un matériau spécial appelé C-PICA pour protéger les engins spatiaux de la chaleur intense lors de leur retour sur Terre. Ce matériau a été développé au centre de recherche Ames de la NASA en Californie.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 29 janvier 2026, la capsule W-5 de Varda Space Industries est revenue sur Terre en utilisant un bouclier thermique fabriqué avec le matériau C-PICA. Varda a obtenu une licence de cette technologie auprès de la NASA et a fabriqué le bouclier protecteur pour sa capsule, ce qui lui a permis de résister à la rentrée atmosphérique.

**Impact** – Cet événement montre comment la technologie de la NASA peut être utilisée par des entreprises privées pour améliorer les voyages spatiaux. Le bouclier thermique C-PICA est plus solide, moins cher et plus efficace que les anciens matériaux. Cela signifie que les capsules spatiales peuvent ramener des objets précieux sur Terre de manière plus sûre et économique.

**Prochaine étape** – La NASA et des entreprises privées comme Varda continueront probablement à collaborer pour utiliser et améliorer cette technologie de bouclier thermique. Cela pourrait rendre les missions spatiales plus sûres et plus fréquentes, avec une meilleure protection pour le matériel et les expériences.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le matériau avancé de bouclier thermique de la NASA a aidé une entreprise privée à ramener en toute sécurité une capsule spatiale sur Terre, montrant un progrès important dans la technologie spatiale.
articles.personality_title_es: La tecnología de escudo térmico de la NASA ayuda a una cápsula espacial privada a regresar con seguridad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – La NASA creó un material especial llamado C-PICA para proteger las naves espaciales del intenso calor que enfrentan al regresar a la Tierra. Este material fue desarrollado en el Centro de Investigación Ames de la NASA en California.

**Qué pasó** – El 29 de enero de 2026, la cápsula W-5 de Varda Space Industries regresó a la Tierra usando un escudo térmico hecho con el material C-PICA. Varda obtuvo la licencia de esta tecnología de la NASA y fabricó el escudo para su cápsula, lo que ayudó a que soportara la reentrada atmosférica.

**Impacto** – Este evento muestra cómo la tecnología de la NASA puede ser usada por empresas privadas para mejorar los viajes espaciales. El escudo térmico C-PICA es más fuerte, más barato y funciona mejor que los materiales antiguos. Esto significa que las cápsulas espaciales pueden traer objetos valiosos de regreso a la Tierra de forma más segura y económica.

**Próximo paso** – La NASA y empresas privadas como Varda probablemente seguirán trabajando juntas para usar y mejorar esta tecnología de escudos térmicos. Esto podría llevar a misiones espaciales más seguras y frecuentes, con mejor protección para equipos y experimentos.

**Resumen en una frase** – El avanzado material de escudo térmico de la NASA ayudó a una empresa privada a traer una cápsula espacial de regreso a la Tierra con seguridad, mostrando un progreso importante en la tecnología espacial.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a sleek, glowing space capsule streaking through a softly clouded sky at sunset, its surface textured to suggest a high-tech, protective heat shield material, with subtle abstract patterns evoking advanced carbon ablative layers, descending gently toward a stylized, serene Silicon Valley landscape below.

articles.title: Curiosity Blog, Sols 4788-4797: Welcome Back from Conjunction
articles.summary: Written by Alex Innanen, Atmospheric Scientist at York University, Toronto Earth planning date: Friday, Jan. 30, 2026 Mars has emerged from its holiday behind the Sun, and we here on Earth have been able to reconnect with Curiosity and get back to work on Mars. Our first planning day last Friday gave Curiosity a full […]
articles.content:
NASA’s Mars rover Curiosity acquired this image using its Mast Camera (Mastcam); it shows the “Nevado Sajama” drill site from November, right next to the location of this weekend’s drill. The new drill site will be to the upper left of the existing hole. Curiosity captured the image on Jan. 25, 2026 — Sol 4789, or Martian day 4,789 of the Mars Science Laboratory mission — at 19:20:37 UTC. NASA/JPL-Caltech/MSSS

Written by Alex Innanen, Atmospheric Scientist at York University, Toronto

Earth planning date: Friday, Jan. 30, 2026

Mars has emerged from its holiday behind the Sun, and we here on Earth have been able to reconnect with Curiosity and get back to work on Mars. Our first planning day last Friday gave Curiosity a full weekend of activities, which wrapped up with getting us ready for our next drill. We checked out a broken white rock in the workspace with APXS, MAHLI, and ChemCam’s laser spectrometer and finished up imaging a sandy area we’ve kept an eye on during conjunction to see if we could catch any wind motion, before taking a small drive to our drill location about 2 meters away (about 6 feet).

This location may look familiar — our next drill will be only a few centimeters away from “Nevado Sajama,” which we drilled back in November. The reason we’ve returned here is to do a rare SAM experiment the instrument’s last container of tetramethylammonium hydroxide (or TMAH, for less of a mouthful). TMAH is a chemical that we can mix with our sample from Nevado Sajama to help identify any organic molecules. SAM had only two containers of TMAH (the first of which we used almost six years ago, so we want to be very certain that everything will go well with this experiment. As a result, we did a rehearsal of the handoff of the sample to SAM in Wednesday’s plan, before we drill this weekend.
articles.reasoning: The article reports on NASA's Mars rover Curiosity resuming scientific operations after a communication hiatus, including a significant experiment to detect organic molecules on Mars using a rare chemical. This represents meaningful progress in space exploration with potential broad scientific impact.
articles.personality_title: NASA's Curiosity rover resumes work on Mars with a key new experiment
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Mars was hidden behind the Sun for a while, making it hard for Earth to communicate with NASA’s Curiosity rover. This period is called conjunction and it pauses many Mars operations.

**What happened** – On January 25, 2026, Curiosity started working again after this break. The team on Earth planned a weekend full of activities for the rover, including checking a broken white rock and moving a short distance to a new drill site near a place called Nevado Sajama. This location was drilled before in November 2025.

**Impact** – This new drill is important because it will use a rare chemical called TMAH to help find organic molecules. Organic molecules are important because they can tell us about past life or conditions on Mars. Curiosity only has two small containers of TMAH, so this experiment needs to be done carefully. This work shows how scientists keep making progress even after breaks.

**What's next step** – Before drilling, the team practiced handling the sample to make sure the experiment goes smoothly. The drill and chemical test will happen soon, and the results could give new clues about Mars’ history.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After a communication break, Curiosity is back to exploring Mars, preparing a rare experiment to search for organic molecules near a previously studied site.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le rover Curiosity de la NASA reprend ses travaux sur Mars avec une expérience clé
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Mars était cachée derrière le Soleil pendant un moment, ce qui rendait la communication avec le rover Curiosity de la NASA difficile. Cette période s’appelle la conjonction et elle interrompt beaucoup d’opérations sur Mars.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 25 janvier 2026, Curiosity a recommencé à travailler après cette pause. L’équipe sur Terre a planifié un week-end chargé d’activités pour le rover, notamment l’examen d’une roche blanche cassée et un court déplacement vers un nouveau site de forage près d’un endroit appelé Nevado Sajama. Ce site avait déjà été foré en novembre 2025.

**Impact** – Ce nouveau forage est important parce qu’il utilisera un produit chimique rare appelé TMAH pour aider à détecter des molécules organiques. Ces molécules sont importantes car elles peuvent révéler des indices sur la vie passée ou les conditions sur Mars. Curiosity n’a que deux petits réservoirs de TMAH, donc cette expérience doit être réalisée avec soin. Ce travail montre comment les scientifiques continuent de progresser même après des pauses.

**Prochaine étape** – Avant le forage, l’équipe a pratiqué la manipulation de l’échantillon pour s’assurer que l’expérience se déroule bien. Le forage et le test chimique auront lieu bientôt, et les résultats pourraient apporter de nouveaux indices sur l’histoire de Mars.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après une pause de communication, Curiosity reprend l’exploration de Mars en préparant une expérience rare pour rechercher des molécules organiques près d’un site déjà étudié.
articles.personality_title_es: El rover Curiosity de la NASA reanuda su trabajo en Marte con un experimento clave
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Marte estuvo oculto detrás del Sol por un tiempo, lo que dificultó la comunicación con el rover Curiosity de la NASA. Este período se llama conjunción y pausa muchas operaciones en Marte.

**Qué pasó** – El 25 de enero de 2026, Curiosity volvió a trabajar después de esta pausa. El equipo en la Tierra planificó un fin de semana lleno de actividades para el rover, incluyendo revisar una roca blanca rota y moverse un poco hacia un nuevo sitio de perforación cerca de un lugar llamado Nevado Sajama. Este sitio ya había sido perforado en noviembre de 2025.

**Impacto** – Esta nueva perforación es importante porque usará un químico raro llamado TMAH para ayudar a encontrar moléculas orgánicas. Las moléculas orgánicas son importantes porque pueden contar sobre vida pasada o condiciones en Marte. Curiosity solo tiene dos pequeños contenedores de TMAH, por lo que el experimento debe hacerse con cuidado. Este trabajo muestra cómo los científicos siguen avanzando incluso después de pausas.

**Próximo paso** – Antes de perforar, el equipo practicó cómo manejar la muestra para asegurar que el experimento salga bien. La perforación y la prueba química ocurrirán pronto, y los resultados podrían dar nuevas pistas sobre la historia de Marte.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Después de una pausa en la comunicación, Curiosity vuelve a explorar Marte, preparando un experimento raro para buscar moléculas orgánicas cerca de un sitio ya estudiado.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of the Martian landscape at dusk featuring Curiosity’s robotic arm gently reaching toward a freshly drilled reddish rock near a small, older drill hole labeled only by subtle texture differences, with soft swirling dust hinting at light wind movement and a distant sun partially obscured behind the horizon, using natural reds, oranges, and muted browns to evoke a calm, hopeful atmosphere of scientific discovery.
